task.title: Setting up the Application Server Resources

context.p: APPThe ROR integration softwareThe AWS integration softwareThe OpenStack integration softwareThe TPS5 integration softwareThe vSphere integration softwareThe Azure integration software requires specific settings and resources in the application server, such as mail settings or a data source.
context.note: When creating the application server resources, you can also deploy a service controller. For details, refer to .
context.p: Proceed as follows to create the resources and make the required settings in the application server:

step.cmd: Open the command prompt (Windows) or a terminal session (UNIX/Linux).
Execute the build-glassfish.xml file in <install_pack_dir>/install as follows:

ul.li: The app-domain domain is created and started.
The settings and resources for APP are created in the application server.
APP (oscm-app.ear) is deployed to the app-domain domain.

A key file for encryption and decryption is generated in the location you specified in the APP_KEY_PATH setting in the configsettings.properties file. By default, this file is named key and located in
<GLASSFISH_HOME>/glassfish/domains/app-domain/config.
The ROR service controller (oscm-app-ror.ear) is deployed to the app-domain domain.
The AWS service controller (oscm-app-aws.ear) is deployed to the app-domain domain.
The OpenStack service controller (oscm-app-openstack.ear) is deployed to the app-domain domain.
The TPS5 service controller (oscm-app-tps5.ear) is deployed to the app-domain domain.
The Azure service controller (oscm-azure-aws.ear) is deployed to the app-domain domain.
The VMware service controller (oscm-app-vmware.ear) is deployed to the app-domain domain.
A data source for the VMware service controller is created in the application server.

step.cmd: Depending on your environment, it may be required to define a proxy server for the app-domain domain in the JVM Options of the application server. A service controller implemented such that it supports proxy communicationThe ROR service controllerThe AWS service controllerThe OpenStack service controllerThe TPS5 service controllerThe VMware service controllerThe Azure service controller can address the corresponding system via the proxy server.
step.info:
To define a proxy server, specify the following JVM options:
-Dhttps.proxyHost
-Dhttps.proxyPort
If authentication is required, specify the following additional settings:
-Dhttps.proxyUser
-Dhttps.proxyPassword
For all direct communication, you need to bypass the proxy server. Specify the hosts which are to be addressed directly and not through the proxy server in the following setting:
-Dhttp.nonProxyHosts For example, APP must not use the configured proxy for Web service calls to :
-Dhttp.nonProxyHosts=localhost|127.0.0.1|myServer*
where myServer is the host on which is running.
In case several service controllers are to run in the same APP domain, and only one of them is to communicate via a proxy server, you need to exclude the target systems of the other service controllers, for example, as follows: -Dhttps.proxyHost=proxy.intern.myserver.com
-Dhttps.proxyPort=8081
-Dhttp.nonProxyHosts=myServer.com|localhost|127.0.0.1|
http://10.140.18.112*|http://myServer.com:8880/templates/*|
https://ror-demo.myServer.com:8014/cfmgapi/endpoint*
After having configured the proxy server, restart the app-domain.

cmd.ph: Depending on your environment, it may be required to provide separate certificates for external and internal communication between and APP. In this case, you can use the secure HTTP listener port (default: 8082).
